user.speaker: user
user.text: can I get some information about service support in case I run into some issues?

agent.speaker: agent
agent.text: IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service concurrently supports multiple versions of Kubernetes. However, when a new version (n) is released, versions up to 2 behind (n-2) are supported. If you need support on worker node operated systems by cluster version, please see the Kubernetes version information. Certain VPC worker node flavors offer GPU support. For more information, see the VPC flavors.

contexts.text:
Keep in mind that some services such as Ingress might require multiple worker nodes for high availability, and you might not be able to run these services or your apps in the smallest size cluster possible.
* Which Kubernetes versions does the service support?

IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service concurrently supports multiple versions of Kubernetes. When a new version (n) is released, versions up to 2 behind (n-2) are supported. Versions more than 2 behind the latest (n-3) are first deprecated and then unsupported.

For more information about supported versions and update actions that you must take to move from one version to another, see [Kubernetes version information](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-cs_versions)
* Which worker node operating systems does the service support?

For a list of supported worker node operated systems by cluster version, see [Kubernetes version information](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-cs_versions).
* Where is the service available?

IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service is available worldwide. You can create clusters in every supported IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service region.

For more information about supported regions, see [Locations](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-regions-and-zonesregions-and-zones).
* Is the service highly available?

Yes. By default, IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service sets up many components such as the cluster master with replicas, anti-affinity, and other options to increase the high availability (HA) of the service. You can increase the redundancy and failure toleration of your cluster worker nodes, storage, networking, and workloads by configuring them in a highly available architecture. For an overview of the default setup and your options to increase HA, see [High availability for IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-ha).

ml.tokens.model_text: IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service concurrently supports multiple versions of Kubernetes

contexts.text:
For more information about what is included in a security patch, refer to the [version change log](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-cs_versionscs_versions_available).
* Does the service offer support for bare metal and GPU?

Certain VPC worker node flavors offer GPU support. For more information, see the [VPC flavors](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/openshift?topic=openshift-vpc-flavors).

Yes, you can provision your worker node as a single-tenant physical bare metal server. Bare metal servers come with high-performance benefits for workloads such as data, GPU, and AI. Additionally, all the hardware resources are dedicated to your workloads, so you don't have to worry about "noisy neighbors".

For more information about available bare metal flavors and how bare metal is different from virtual machines, see [Physical machines (bare metal)](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/openshift?topic=openshift-planning_worker_nodesbm).
* What is the smallest size cluster that I can make?

Your cluster must have at least 2 worker nodes to run default Kubernetes and OpenShift Container Platform components. You can't have a cluster with 0 worker nodes, and you can't power off or suspend billing for your worker nodes. Additionally, the type of cluster and the number of worker pools that you have can impact the size of your cluster.



* Single zone clusters: [Create a cluster](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/openshift?topic=openshift-clusters) with 2 worker nodes in the default worker pool.
* Multizone clusters: You must [create a cluster](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/openshift?topic=openshift-clusters) with 1 worker node per zone in the worker pool.

 What is the smallest size cluster that I can make? 

Your cluster must have at least 1 worker node to run default Kubernetes components. You can't have a cluster with 0 worker nodes, and you can't power off or suspend billing for your worker nodes. Additionally, the type of cluster and the number of worker pools that you have can impact the size of your cluster.



* Single zone clusters: [Create a cluster](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-clusters) with 1 worker node in the default worker pool.
* Multizone clusters: You must [create a cluster](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-clusters) with 1 worker node per zone in the worker pool.

agent.original_text:
IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service provides support for multiple versions of Kubernetes, with new versions (n) being supported along with versions up to 2 behind (n-2). Versions more than 2 behind the latest (n-3) are first deprecated and then unsupported. For a list of supported worker node operating systems by cluster version, you can refer to the Kubernetes version information in the IBM Cloud documentation.
If you encounter issues or need assistance, you can reach out to the IBM Cloud support team. They are available 24/7 and can be contacted through the IBM Cloud console, by phone, or via email. The support options available to you depend on your IBM Cloud account type and level. For more information, you can refer to the IBM Cloud documentation on getting help and support.
In addition to official support, IBM also offers various resources to help you troubleshoot and resolve issues on your own. These include a comprehensive knowledge base, a community forum where you can ask questions and share knowledge with other IBM Cloud users, and documentation and tutorials on using IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service.
If you are unable to find a solution to your issue through these resources, you may want to consider engaging an IBM Cloud partner or consultant for additional assistance. IBM Cloud partners are certified experts who can provide consulting, migration, and management services to help you get the most out of IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service. You can find a list of IBM Cloud partners on the IBM Cloud website.
